body: Updated.
Updated.

Works for me but it'd be nice if there was some user feedback so you know if it actually took a screenshot or not when you press the keys. Plus if it told you where it saved the file that'd be nice too.

> Works for me but it'd be nice if there was some user feedback so you know if it actually took a screenshot or not when you press the keys. Plus if it told you where it saved the file that'd be nice too.

I guess you just tested the shellmap which has no chat dialog so it does not display debug messages. I added notifications in-game without full path however to avoid line overflow issues.
Works very nice, thanks :+1:
I commented earlier (now hidden in an outdated thread) that supporting formats like bmp and tiff is silly, and the general opinion in IRC at the time seemed to agree.
Updated regarding the thread unsafe `Game.Debug` line.

> I commented earlier (now hidden in an outdated thread) that supporting formats like bmp and tiff is silly, and the general opinion in IRC at the time seemed to agree.

Those formats are supported by .NET out of the box. There is no way of removing support. I can only hide them which is dumb. We have sane defaults here.

You are going out of your way to add engine support for those formats, including a hidden preference for them.  This is a giant edge case that is just waiting to crash at some exciting gameplay moment that somebody is wanting to capture.  libgdiplus does not have a good track record for things like this.

Your argument does not make much sense. If you think libgdiplus is unstable and will crash (no evidence provided so far) then this whole undertaking is futile. No one will probably ever change from the default PNG format and the small percentage that wants something else will file a feature request immediately that you will then also have to talk down every now and then.

> No one will probably ever change from the default PNG format

That is the core of my argument.  Adding support for bmp, tiff, and even jpg (although one could reasonably argue to keep that) introduces extra code and API surface area (we now depend implicitly on libtiff etc) for no real benefit.  You know as well as, and probably better than, anyone that libgdiplus is fragile and causes problems for packagers.

We should not be introducing new hidden settings for features that maybe 2 people in our entire player base might use but which nobody will need. If somebody has a use case that isn't covered by png then they can convert the lossless png to whatever format they want.

Please give me a usecase where somebody would want a bmp or tiff screenshot, and explain why those cases are important enough for us to support natively, while ignoring people who want PCX or WebP format screenshots.

The uncompressed BMP screenshot feature from Valve's GoldSrc engine was used to create an AVI for high-quality video rendering. https://wiki.openttd.org/Screenshot#Description offers support for BMP, PNG and even PCX. It is common in the free software world to offer more choices. It is arrogant and ignorant to call that poorly designed. The two people who want or need TIFF for whatever reason can then just install libtiff. Actually they don't have to, because libgdiplus is already installed and depends on it. I still fail to see your problem.

https://xkcd.com/1172/

If not having tiff, bmp or gif available breaks their workflow, they're doing something wrong. There's no point in supporting extra formats. We should be displaying a reasonable number of options to our users and screenshot format doesn't make the list imo. It's really not that hard to convert an image between formats...
On 2015-05-09, at 12:02 PM, Matthias Mailänder notifications@github.com wrote:

> The uncompressed BMP screenshot feature from Valve's GoldSrc engine was used to create an AVI for high-quality video rendering. https://wiki.openttd.org/Screenshot#Description offers support for BMP, PNG and even PCX. It is common in the free software world to offer more choices. It is arrogant and ignorant to call that poorly designed. The two people who want or need TIFF for whatever reason can then just install libtiff. I still fail to see your problem.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
If we ever tie this to a settings GUI we can leave the ones we don't like out. For now I would like to put this discussion back on topic: review and enhance the screenshot function.

The argument made against multiple formats here has been on the topic of us adding more code to our product when the user can easily solve this elsewhere (where it is meant to be solved).

There is no reason to hide features form the GUI, we just shouldn't add features we don't _need_.

I am bit tired of that argument, but I guess I have to repeat myself. The whole imaging is done by the .NET framework. I did not implement a single line of code that interfaces with libpng, libjpeg or libtiff. We got the feature set for free. There is no way I can undo that. We will need to ship our own version of Mono/.NET where some System.Imaging features are removed. Are you seriously suggesting that?
I think it is unfair to let this wait for promised patches. They can be integrated later.
The top google link for "gl pack state" is https://www.opengl.org/archives/resources/features/KilgardTechniques/oglpitfall/, which describes why this is wrong and how to fix it.
If I understand it correctly, then someone needs to use a screen resolution that is not dividable by 4 to break this. That seems to be quite unlikely.
Updated. This appears to fix my transparency artifact problem. Thanks!
Works nicely here :+1:
Needs rebase.
Rebased.
Updated to also set PackRowLength and extended the unsafe block.
Updated to use https://www.opengl.org/sdk/docs/man2/xhtml/glPushClientAttrib.xml now.
Thanks for the great feature :+1:

[Changelog](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/wiki/Changelog-%28bleed%29/_compare/c3a8f5783350c38783daf8562bf17243e5f36adf...f31caa9213dfed39d50eea3b698cf354bff989d0)

This should also be mentioned in the newspost for the playtest.
Thanks to the reviewers. I learned a lot about OpenGL while doing this.
